content.user_title: Apply Anthony Fu's Web Development Best Practices
content.value_statement: Projects often lack consistent tooling and configuration across team members. This skill provides opinionated best practices from Anthony Fu including TypeScript, ESLint, Vitest, and CI/CD configurations that ensure consistent code quality and developer experience across any web project.
actual_capabilities: Recommends pnpm with @antfu/ni for consistent package management commands
Defines TypeScript strict mode settings with ESNext targets
Configures Vitest testing framework with proper conventions
Sets up GitHub Actions CI/CD workflows via reusable configurations
Specifies VSCode extensions and settings for consistent editor experience
limitations: Does not execute any commands or modify project files directly
Requires manual implementation of configurations in your project
Follows opinionated conventions that may not suit all project requirements

output_examples.input: What ESLint configuration should I use?

best_practices: Use @antfu/ni (ni, nr, nx) commands for consistent package management across your team regardless of package manager preference
Configure simple-git-hooks with lint-staged to automatically run linters on staged files before commit
Set up TypeScript with ESNext target and strict mode enabled from project start to catch type errors early
anti_patterns: Mixing different package managers (npm, yarn, pnpm) in the same project without using @antfu/ni
Disabling TypeScript strict mode or ESLint rules without understanding the implications
Skipping pre-commit hooks and CI checks to save time - this leads to inconsistent code quality

faq.question: What is @antfu/eslint-config and why should I use it?
faq.answer: @antfu/eslint-config is a shareable ESLint configuration created by Anthony Fu. It combines ESLint rules with Prettier formatting into a single, opinionated config. It reduces configuration overhead and ensures consistent code style across projects.

faq.question: Do I need to use pnpm to follow these practices?
faq.answer: While pnpm is recommended for its efficiency and disk space savings, @antfu/ni allows team members to use their preferred package manager (pnpm, npm, yarn, bun) while maintaining consistent commands across the team.

faq.question: How do I integrate Vitest with these practices?
faq.answer: Install Vitest and configure it with the recommended settings from this skill. Use @vitest/ui for visual test exploration and ensure your test files follow the naming convention (*.test.ts or *.spec.ts) for automatic discovery.

faq.question: Can I use these practices with Vue or React projects?
faq.answer: Yes. The configurations support Vue and React/Next.js. When configuring ESLint, enable the vue or react option in @antfu/eslint-config. The TypeScript and testing configurations work across frameworks.

faq.question: What VSCode settings are recommended?
faq.answer: Use the VSCode extensions and settings outlined in this skill for format-on-save, ESLint integration, and TypeScript support. This ensures your editor automatically applies code quality checks as you write code.

faq.question: How do I migrate an existing project to these practices?
faq.answer: Start by installing the required dependencies and creating the configuration files. Run ESLint with --fix to auto-fix style issues. Gradually adopt the other practices like pre-commit hooks and CI/CD. The migration can be done incrementally.
